title: The language of wine
intro: For some, it's a companion when it comes to relaxing at the end of a hard day. For others, it's a complex elixir which requires study and involves almost a ritual. We are talking about wine. Rob and Sam talk about the life of a sommelier and teach you related vocabulary along the way.
this_week_question: In 2018, a bottle of wine dating back to 1774 sold at auction in eastern France for a record-breaking price. Do you know how much it was sold for?
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: someone who enjoys a particular thing and knows a lot about it
someone who serves and give advice about wine in a restaurant
word used to emphasise the amount of something; nothing but
describes someone’s ability to distinguish and appreciate different tastes
changes information into something we can use or understand

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Sam.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And I’m Rob.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Rob, would you describe yourself as a wine connoisseur ?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: If you mean am I someone who enjoys wine and knows a lot about it, then no – although the ‘enjoy’ part is true – particularly a nice glass of red.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Of course, wine might not be everybody’s cup of tea – not something they like – but wine has been an important part of history and language.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And even if you don’t drink alcohol, wine can be used as a commodity you can invest in and sell at an auction.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: And that brings me on to my quiz question, Rob. In 2018, a bottle of wine dating back to 1774 sold at auction in eastern France for a record-breaking price. Do you know how much it was sold for? Was it…

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I know wine can fetch a high price – but not as high as some of those options, so I’ll say a) $20,800.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: I’ll reveal the answer later on. But let’s talk more about wine now. A glass of the stuff can be sipped and savoured or just glugged.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Glug is a good word, meaning drink in large gulps or mouthfuls - not something a wine expert would do. For some people, drinking and serving wine is almost an art-form.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: If you go to a restaurant, there might be a sommelier – a person whose job is to serve and give advice about wine. They may have had years of training to learn about the different types of wine and the individual flavours or aromas, known as notes .

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: This job has fascinated journalist and author Bianca Bosker. She wrote a book called ‘Cork Dorks’.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: And here she is talking on the BBC World Service programme The Why Factor describing her fascination with sommeliers…

transcript.author: Bianca Bosker, writer and author
transcript.text: These were people who had taken wine, which I always thought of as a thing of pleasure, something you turn to after a long stressful day, and turned it into something approaching sheer God-awful pain. They licked rocks, trained their palates , they divorced their spouses to spend more time reviewing flash cards - they had hired voice coaches and memory coaches, they took dance classes to learn how to move more gracefully across the dining room floor.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Like me, Bianca thought drinking wine was a pleasurable activity – something that helped her relax after a long stressful day. So she was surprised at how sommeliers turned this activity into “something approaching sheer God-awful pain”.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: The word sheer is used to emphasise the amount of something – or to mean ‘nothing but’. She thought the work of a sommelier was nothing but pain – they seemed to dedicate their life to wine!

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: One thing a sommelier does is train their palate – this is their ability to distinguish and appreciate different tastes – and identify types of good wine from their taste. I guess this is quite important.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: But divorcing their spouses does sound a bit extreme!  I’m afraid I wouldn’t take it so seriously - I’ll stick to drinking poorer quality, cheap red wine – sometimes called plonk !

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: WeIl, Rob, cheap wine doesn’t always have to be poor quality. Interestingly, there is some evidence that shows we only think wine tastes better because it’s more expensive.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Ah yes, this is research Hilke Plassmann from INSEAD Business School in France spoke about on the BBC World Service’s Why Factor programme. She’s been looking into what influences consumer behaviour…

transcript.author: Hilke Plassmann, from INSEAD Business School in France
transcript.text: The price tag affects that region in your brain that encodes your liking of the taste, so in other words, you not only think that you like the more expensive wine more, you feel you like the more expensive wine more, because your brain region that encodes this feeling is influenced by the price tag.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: So, our brain is possibly playing tricks on us. When we see the price tag on a bottle of wine, our brain encodes the information and tells us how it should taste. Encodes means changes the information into something that we can use or understand. Drinking more expensive wine makes you think it tastes better. So perhaps, when buying supermarket wine or wine in a restaurant, it may be better telling yourself that the cheaper option is OK!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I’ll drink to that! But I wonder how that most expensive bottle of wine ever sold at auction tastes? The one dating back to 1774 that you asked me about.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: So you thought it sold for $20,800, but sorry, Rob, that’s too cheap. It was in fact sold for $120,800. I assume it wasn’t drunk.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I hope not. Well, I think I’ll stick to my plonk for now, Sam. Plonk was one of our vocabulary words today and describes cheap, poor quality wine.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: We also mentioned a connoisseur – someone who enjoys a particular thing and knows a lot about it.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: A sommelier is someone who serves and gives advice about wine in a restaurant

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Sheer is a word used to emphasise the amount of something – or to mean ‘nothing but’.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: A palate describes someone’s ability to distinguish and appreciate different tastes.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Finally, encodes means changes information into something we can use or understand. But now we’re out of time so ‘cheers’ everyone.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Thanks for listening and goodbye.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Goodbye.

authors: Hilke Plassmann, from INSEAD Business School in France
